title: 114_s953
content: The Act titled the "Eastern Nevada Land Implementation Improvement Act" facilitates pinyon-juniper related projects in Lincoln County, Nevada. The Eastern Nevada Land Implementation Improvement Act amends the Lincoln County Land Act of 2000 to facilitate development and implementation of comprehensive, cost-effective pinyon-juniper related projects. The Eastern Nevada Land Implementation Improvement Act aims to facilitate hazardous fuels reduction projects and wildfire prevention planning, particularly for pinyon-juniper dominated landscapes, within the County. It also includes waiver of fees for rights-of-way applications submitted by local or regional governments to deliver government-provided services to land conveyed under the Act. The Eastern Nevada Land Implementation Improvement Act requires cooperative agreements between the Bureau of Land Management and the County for law enforcement and planning activities related to wilderness areas, cultural resources, the Silver State OHV Trail, and land disposal planning. The Eastern Nevada Land Implementation Improvement Act mandates cooperative agreements between the Bureau of Land Management and the County for various activities related to wilderness areas, cultural resources, the Silver State OHV Trail, and land disposal planning. Additionally, the Act addresses the availability of a special account under the Lincoln County Conservation, Recreation, and Development Act of 2004 for the development and implementation of utility corridors and rights-of-way. The Eastern Nevada Land Implementation Improvement Act mandates cooperative agreements between the Bureau of Land Management and the County for hazardous fuels reduction, wildfire prevention planning, and restoration projects within the County. Additionally, it waives fees for rights-of-way applications submitted by local or regional governments for delivering government-provided services to conveyed land. Cooperative agreements between the Bureau of Land Management and the County are required for various activities related to wilderness, cultural resources, the Silver State OHV Trail, and land disposal. Proceeds under the Lincoln County Land Act are to be disposed of accordingly. Proceeds from the Lincoln County Land Act of 2000 and the Lincoln County Conservation, Recreation, and Development Act of 2004 are to be allocated to schools, transportation, and the Lincoln County Regional Development Authority or any other County economic development organization. Certain land in the utility corridor is not withdrawn. Certain land in the utility corridor, excluding specific sections, is not withdrawn according to an amendment in the Lincoln County Conservation, Recreation, and Development Act of 2004. SEC. 3. MT. MORIAH WILDERNESS, HIGH SCHELLS WILDERNESS, AND ARC DOME WILDERNESS BOUNDARY ADJUSTMENTS. Amendments to the Pam White Wilderness Act include adjustments to the boundaries of the Mt. Moriah Wilderness and High Schells Wilderness. The Mt. Moriah Wilderness boundary is expanded to include specific lands identified on maps dated 2006 and 2014. The High Schells Wilderness boundary is adjusted to include specific lands and exclude others, as outlined in maps dated 2014. Amendments to the Nevada Wilderness Protection Act of 1989 are made to accommodate these changes. The Arc Dome Wilderness boundary is adjusted to exclude specific land identified as 'Exclude from Wilderness' on a map dated November 3, 2014. An amendment is made to implement a conservation plan benefiting fish and wildlife species in the Virgin River, Nevada.
